page.title: 17Natural History.
page.content: The small areas of woodland contain ash, oak, beech and silver birch. The fields are divided mainly by ditches and hedges in which grow hawthorn, hazel, elder, honeysuckle and pussy-willow. Wild flowers include primrose, bluebell, cuckoo-pint, celandine, violet and cowslip. Birds of the fields, woods and hedges include buzzards, sparrow-hawks, kestrels, blackbirds, thrushes, tits, finches, robins, woodpeckers, pigeons, starlings, crows, rooks, magpies, jackdaws, partridge and pheasant. The River Frome is home to moorhen, grebes dippers, kingfishers and mallard. In summer swallows, martins, cuckoos, curlews and flycatchers visit. the river contains trout, perch, pike, dace, gudgeon and crayfish. Wild animals include fox, badger, roe deer, hare and squirrel.
